study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between dietary intake, particularly omega-6 fatty acids, and brown adipose tissue (BAT) activity in healthy males.
results_summary: The study found that lower omega-6 fatty acid intake was significantly associated with detected BAT activity, suggesting a potential link between dietary omega-6 and BAT function. BAT presence was also linked to lower visceral adipose tissue and higher serum IL-6 levels during cold exposure.
population_specificity: 28 healthy non-smoking males aged 21-42 years, including normal-weight and overweight/obese individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Omega-6 fatty acids, specifically arachidonic acid (AA), could enhance the effectiveness of doxorubicin (dox) chemotherapy in Her2-amplified breast cancer cells by increasing lipid peroxidation and 4-HNE generation while sparing cardiomyocytes.
results_summary: AA increased lipid peroxidation, 4-HNE generation, apoptosis, cellular dox concentration, and dox cytotoxicity in Her2-amplified breast cancer cell lines (SK-BR-3 and AU565) without harming cultured cardiomyocytes. AA also inhibited Rlip functions, suggesting a synergistic effect with dox or Rlip inhibitors.
population_specificity: Her2-amplified breast cancer cell lines (SK-BR-3 and AU565) and immortalized cardiomyocyte cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of omega-6 fatty acid arachidonic acid (AA) with omega-3 fatty acids (EPA and DHA) on nitric oxide bioavailability and fatty acid composition in endothelial cells.
results_summary: AA did not affect nitric oxide (NO) or peroxynitrite (ONOO-) release, unlike EPA and DHA, which increased NO levels. AA treatment decreased the EPA/AA ratio 4-fold, indicating a negative impact on omega-3 fatty acid content.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Neuroaspis PLP10™, containing omega-6 fatty acids, could improve Parkinson's disease symptoms and delay disease progression when used as an adjuvant to conventional treatment.
results_summary: Neuroaspis PLP10™ supplementation significantly delayed Parkinson's disease progression according to UPDRS scores (p ≤ 0.05) compared to placebo over 30 months. The study suggests potential benefits of omega-6 fatty acids in managing Parkinson's disease symptoms.
population_specificity: 40 patients with Parkinson's disease.
effective_dosage: 1800 mg gamma-Linolenic acid and 3150 mg Linoleic acid (1:1 w/w), administered once daily in a 20 ml dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze red blood cell membrane fatty acid profiles in breast cancer patients to identify potential biomarkers and therapeutic targets related to Omega-6 Fatty Acids.
results_summary: The study found that breast cancer patients had higher levels of Omega-6 Fatty Acids (C18:2 and C20:4) compared to controls, suggesting that Omega-6 pathways are favored in these patients. These findings indicate potential targets for treatments and nutritional guidelines.
population_specificity: Recently diagnosed breast cancer patients before starting chemotherapy treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of an Omega-3/Omega-6 fatty acid supplement in reducing ADHD symptoms and related behavioral problems in preschool children at risk for ADHD.
results_summary: The study found moderate positive effects on parent- and teacher-rated ADHD symptoms, internalizing symptoms, and externalizing symptoms, though results require replication in larger samples for stronger conclusions.
population_specificity: Preschool children with elevated ADHD symptoms (n=40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acid sources on ovarian response and embryo quality in Boer does undergoing superovulation treatment.
results_summary: Linseed oil (LO) supplementation resulted in a higher number of ova/embryos recovered and transferable embryos compared to soybean oil (SO), palm oil (PO), and control (CO), while also preventing premature luteal regression. Other treatments showed no significant differences in ovulation numbers or estrous response.
population_specificity: Pluriparous Boer does (goats)
effective_dosage: 300 g of experimental supplements (LO, SO, PO, or CO) daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of saturated fatty acids (SFAs) and omega-6 PUFAs on the incorporation of omega-3 PUFAs into milk and tissues of lactating mice and their offspring.
results_summary: High-linoleic-acid (HLA) diets decreased omega-3 PUFA concentrations in multiple pup tissues compared to high-SFA diets, suggesting that omega-6 PUFAs suppress omega-3 PUFA incorporation in neonates. Both SAT and HLA diets reduced milk omega-3 PUFA concentrations compared to the low-fat diet.
population_specificity: Lactating CD-1 mice and their offspring.
effective_dosage: 12% high-linoleic-acid oil (HLA) or 12% saturated oil (SAT) added to diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Omega-6 Fatty Acids (O6-PUFA) could reduce cancer-related fatigue (CRF) in breast cancer survivors compared to Omega-3 Fatty Acids (O3-PUFA).
results_summary: O6-PUFA supplementation significantly reduced CRF scores compared to O3-PUFA, with the largest benefit observed in participants with severe baseline fatigue. O6-PUFA also significantly decreased proinflammatory markers in the TNF-α signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors 4-36 months posttreatment with a CRF score of ≥4/10.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association of plasma and erythrocyte ω-6 fatty acids with oxidative stress biomarkers in breast cancer patients.
results_summary: Plasma and erythrocyte ω-6 fatty acids showed positive associations with anti-inflammatory and antioxidant factors, respectively, while the ω-6/ω-3 ratio in plasma was inversely associated with the anti-inflammatory factor.
population_specificity: Ninety-five women with recently diagnosed breast cancer and no previous treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic potential of omega-6 fatty acids by examining their effects on antioxidant markers and matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) in a coronary heart disease-induced rat model.
results_summary: Omega-6 fatty acids significantly reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS) and malondialdehyde (MDA) while increasing antioxidant enzyme activities (SOD, catalase, Gpx, AChE). They also downregulated MMP-2 and MMP-9 mRNA and protein expression in coronary heart disease-induced rats.
population_specificity: Coronary heart disease-induced rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association of heavy alcohol consumption with changes in Omega-6 and Omega-3 fatty acid levels and their inflammatory effects in alcohol-dependent patients without clinical liver injury.
results_summary: The study found a pro-inflammatory shift in the Omega-6:Omega-3 ratio, particularly in females with mild liver injury, and noted sex-based differences in fatty acid responses to heavy drinking. Males showed increased DHA and EPA levels, while females had lower DHA and no comparable rise in EPA.
population_specificity: 114 heavy-drinking alcohol-dependent patients (aged 21-65) without clinical liver injury, grouped by ALT levels.

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acid supplementation for treating dry eye syndrome (DES).
results_summary: The study found modest improvements in tear function parameters (e.g., TBUT, Schirmer's test) and subjective symptoms (e.g., OSDI, DESS) in some trials, but evidence was insufficient to strongly recommend omega-3 and omega-6 as standalone DES treatments.
population_specificity: 2591 patients with dry eye syndrome across fifteen studies.
effective_dosage: Not specified (different proportions of omega-3 and omega-6 were used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of caloric restriction on erythrocyte lipid composition, particularly omega-6 fatty acids, and compare these changes with skeletal muscle fatty acid profiles.
results_summary: Caloric restriction significantly modified erythrocyte fatty acid composition, particularly omega-6 fatty acids, and showed positive correlations with skeletal muscle fatty acids for monounsaturated, polyunsaturated, and omega-6 fatty acids, but not for saturated or omega-3 fatty acids.
population_specificity: 11 healthy men, athletes in post-exercise conditions

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increasing or decreasing omega-6 fatty acid intake affects cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors or clinical events.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant effects of increased or decreased omega-6 intake on CVD risk factors like blood lipids and blood pressure, and no data on clinical CVD events. Very few trials with small participant numbers were identified.
population_specificity: Healthy adults or adults at high risk of CVD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the role of Omega-6 Fatty Acids in relation to psychiatric distress, particularly how increased Omega-6 levels correlate with depressive symptoms when fish consumption decreases.
results_summary: The study found that higher Omega-6 levels, coupled with reduced fish intake, elevate the risk of clinical depressive symptoms. It also highlights that rebalancing fatty acid compositions toward Mediterranean diet patterns may reduce psychiatric distress.
population_specificity: Military personnel (implied by context, though not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the effects of omega-3/6 fatty acids on the STAT6 signaling pathway involved in IgE production in allergic individuals.
results_summary: The study found that DHA, EPA, and DPA decreased SEAP secretion (a proxy for IgE production), while AA increased it, confirming their respective inhibitory and stimulatory roles in IL-4R/IL-13R signaling. The results were statistically significant, supporting the hypothesis.
population_specificity: In vitro HEK-Blue IL-4/IL-13 reporter cell line model (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between dietary ratios of ω-6/ω-3 PUFAs and muscle mass in diabetic patients undergoing hemodialysis.
results_summary: A higher dietary ratio of ω-6/ω-3 PUFAs was associated with reduced muscle mass in hemodialysis patients, while adequate intake of ω-3 PUFAs correlated with higher muscle mass.
population_specificity: 69 diabetic patients undergoing hemodialysis (average age 63.0 ± 10.4 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified for ω-6 PUFAs; AI for ω-3 PUFAs was 1.6 g/d (male) and 1.1 g/d (female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the differential health effects of n-6 fatty acids on cardiovascular disease outcomes, focusing on recent human epidemiological and interventional studies.
results_summary: The study found mixed evidence regarding n-6 fatty acids' impact on CVD outcomes, with effects varying within the n-6 series and influenced by ethnicity and background health status. Data from developing countries were sparse, highlighting the need for further research.
population_specificity: Human populations, with noted variability by ethnicity and health status.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Omega-6 fatty acids (PUFAs) in reducing osteoarthritis symptoms and inflammation, as well as their role in decreasing reliance on NSAIDs.
results_summary: Omega-6 fatty acids, particularly EPA, demonstrated anti-inflammatory effects, inhibited catabolic processes, and stimulated anabolic processes in joint cartilage, effectively reducing osteoarthritis symptoms and potentially lowering the need for NSAIDs.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis (OA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of omega-6 fatty acids in improving lipid profiles and their potential effects on cardiovascular disease and diabetes-related complications.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that omega-6 fatty acids may improve lipid profiles in healthy individuals and type 2 diabetic patients, but their overall role remains largely unknown. No significant effects on glucose control, hypertension, or microvascular complications were noted.
population_specificity: Primarily type 2 diabetic patients, with a noted need for future research on type 1 diabetic patients.

study_goal: To determine if oral supplementation with omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids reduces inflammatory marker HLA-DR expression in patients with dry eye syndrome (DES).
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in HLA-DR-positive cells and fluorescence intensity in the fatty acids group, suggesting anti-inflammatory effects. While no significant difference was observed in symptoms and signs, there was a tendency toward improvement in the treatment group.
population_specificity: Adults with mild to moderate dry eye syndrome in France and Italy.
effective_dosage: Three capsules daily (specific omega-6 content not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether interventions containing Omega-6 fatty acids, combined with other components, could reduce disease activity and disability progression in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The PLP10 intervention (containing Omega-6 fatty acids) significantly reduced the annualized relapse rate by 64% and decreased the risk of sustained disability progression by 86% compared to placebo, with no reported adverse events. Interventions A and C showed no significant efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-65 with relapsing-remitting MS (EDSS score 0.0-5.5), excluding those with recent relapses, immunosuppressant use, or other severe conditions.
effective_dosage: Administered orally once daily, 30 minutes before dinner (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-fat diets rich in omega-6 fatty acids versus omega-3 fatty acids on UVB-induced skin carcinogenesis in mice.
results_summary: The study found that a high-fat diet rich in omega-6 fatty acids (HFML) was associated with higher tumor multiplicity, larger tumor sizes, and increased levels of proinflammatory cytokines compared to a diet rich in omega-3 fatty acids (HFFO). Omega-6 fatty acids appeared to promote UVB-induced skin carcinogenesis more than omega-3 fatty acids.
population_specificity: SKH-1 mice exposed to UVB radiation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (high-fat diet composition described, but exact dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of fullerene (C(60)) on carp brain cells pre-treated with omega-6 fatty acids (linoleic acid, LA) and omega-3 fatty acids (DHA), focusing on oxidative stress markers.
results_summary: Pre-treatment with omega-6 (LA) and omega-3 (DHA) reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS) and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances (TBARS) in carp brain cells, with fullerene (C(60)) showing antioxidant effects. Glutathione (GSH) levels increased in some groups exposed to C(60), suggesting modulation of antioxidant pathways.
population_specificity: Carp brain cells (Cyprinus carpio, Cyprinidae)
effective_dosage: Pre-treatment with PUFA for 48 hours, followed by C(60) exposure for 2 hours (specific concentrations not provided)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Omega-6 Fatty Acids (specifically arachidonic acid, AA) influence tumor cell migration in malignant gliomas via FABP7.
results_summary: AA-bound FABP7 stimulated cell migration in U87 MG cells by activating cyclooxygenase-2 and reducing peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ levels, contrasting with DHA's inhibitory effects. The study suggests AA may promote tumor infiltration, worsening prognosis.
population_specificity: U87 malignant glioma cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-6 fatty acids could protect Ppt1-deficient neurons and neuroprogenitor cells from oxidative stress and apoptosis in a model of infantile neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis (INCL).
results_summary: The study found that omega-6 fatty acids, along with omega-3, protected Ppt1-deficient cells from ER- and oxidative stress and suppressed apoptosis, suggesting potential neuroprotective effects in INCL.
population_specificity: Cultured neurons and neuroprogenitor cells from mice lacking Ppt1, modeling INCL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the interactions between omega-6 fatty acids (LA) and IGF signal transduction pathways and their impact on colon cancer cell survival and proliferation.
results_summary: The study found that LA enhanced IGF-IR phosphorylation and downstream signaling molecules (Akt, Erk), suggesting a potential mitogenic effect on HCT116 cells, reducing apoptotic activity.
population_specificity: Colon cancer cells (HCT116 cell line)

study_goal: To evaluate the theoretical rationale and effectiveness of omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids in treating ADHD symptoms.
results_summary: Some RCTs showed no improvement in ADHD symptoms, while others reported reductions, particularly in children with inattentive ADHD or comorbid conditions. The evidence remains inconclusive, and the treatment is not currently recommended as evidence-based.
population_specificity: Children with ADHD, including those with inattentive type and comorbid problems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of omega-3/6 fatty acids in reducing ADHD symptoms in children and adolescents.
results_summary: A majority did not respond to omega-3/6 treatment, but a subgroup (26%) showed significant symptom reduction. After 6 months, 47% of participants exhibited meaningful improvement, particularly those with inattentive ADHD and comorbid neurodevelopmental disorders.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents (8-18 years) with ADHD.
study_duration: 6 months (3-month placebo-controlled phase followed by 3-month open-label phase)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how Omega-6 fatty acids (specifically linoleic acid) and other polyunsaturated fatty acids regulate stearoyl-CoA desaturase (SCD) activity and influence serum triglyceride levels.
results_summary: The study found that linoleic acid (LA) and eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) significantly reduced SCD mRNA levels and sterol response element binding protein-1c mRNA, correlating with lower serum triglycerides, while α-linolenic acid (ALA) did not show the same effect. The SCD index was strongly correlated with serum triglyceride levels, suggesting a regulatory role for these fatty acids in lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: 23 subjects in a controlled clinical setting and Hep G2 cells in vitro.
effective_dosage: Not specified for human subjects; in vitro EC50 for LA was 0.50μM and for EPA was 1.67μM.
study_duration: 6 weeks per diet in a crossover study; 24-hour incubations for Hep G2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of topical alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) and linoleic acid (LA) in treating dry eye signs and inflammatory changes in a mouse model.
results_summary: Topical ALA significantly reduced corneal fluorescein staining, CD11b(+) cell number, and inflammatory cytokine expression (IL-1alpha, TNF-alpha) in dry eye-induced mice. LA effects were not highlighted, but ALA demonstrated anti-inflammatory and therapeutic benefits.
population_specificity: Mice with induced dry eye syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of two different enteral supplements (Impact® Powder Extra and Standard) on leptin levels and nutritional status in Crohn's disease patients during prednisolone treatment.
results_summary: Both supplements improved leptin levels, BMI, and total cholesterol by week 5, though leptin increases were transient due to prednisolone withdrawal. Clinical and biochemical markers improved, but triglyceride levels increased significantly in the Standard group.
population_specificity: 31 Crohn's disease patients with active disease undergoing prednisolone treatment.

study_goal: To assess the effects of omega-6 fatty acids (6-Impact Powder) as adjuvant therapy on proinflammatory and anti-inflammatory cytokine profiles in patients with active Crohn's disease.
results_summary: The 6-Impact Powder group showed significant changes in concentrations of multiple cytokines (interleukin-1beta, interleukin-6, interferon-gamma, monocyte chemoattractant protein-1, interleukin-2, interleukin-4, interleukin-5, and interleukin-10), indicating a broader immunomodulatory effect compared to omega-3 fatty acids.
population_specificity: 31 patients with active Crohn's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a high-fat diet rich in omega-6 fatty acids on colon carcinogenesis and inflammatory response in rats, and whether quercetin or beta-carotene supplementation could mitigate these effects.
results_summary: A high-fat diet rich in omega-6 fatty acids increased aberrant crypt foci (ACF) formation and upregulated iNOS expression but did not significantly affect COX-2 expression or PGE2 levels. Quercetin and beta-carotene reduced ACF formation in high-fat diet-fed rats but did not significantly impact tumor incidence or inflammatory markers.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to azoxymethane (AOM)-induced colon carcinogenesis.
effective_dosage: Not specified for omega-6 fatty acids; quercetin or beta-carotene supplementation details not provided.
study_duration: Sacrificed at 8 weeks (ACF assessment) and 33 weeks (tumor assessment) after last AOM treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of omega-6 fatty acids (specifically arachidonic acid) versus omega-3 fatty acids on outcomes after spinal cord injury in rats.
results_summary: The study found that treatment with arachidonic acid (an omega-6 PUFA) significantly worsened outcomes after spinal cord injury compared to controls, including poorer locomotor performance and increased damage. In contrast, omega-3 PUFAs showed neuroprotective effects.
population_specificity: Rats with induced spinal cord injury (lateral hemisection or compression injury).
effective_dosage: Not specified for omega-6 PUFAs (timing: injected 30 min after injury).
study_duration: Effects monitored up to 6 weeks post-injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different ratios of omega-6 to omega-3 fatty acids in diets affect allergic reactions and immune responses in mice sensitized to cow β-lactoglobulin.
results_summary: Omega-6-rich diets (O6H) showed no allergy alleviation and promoted a stronger Th2 immune response, while omega-3-rich diets (O3H and O3O6) reduced allergic severity and favored a Th1 immune response. O6H mice exhibited higher IL-4 levels and lower rectal temperatures post-challenge compared to omega-3-fed groups.
population_specificity: Three-week-old Balb/c mice (n=20/group).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary ratios: O6H = 10:1, O3O6 = 4:1, O3H = 1:4 omega-6 to omega-3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of individual omega-6 fatty acids on preventing chemically induced diabetes mellitus in experimental animals.
results_summary: Prior exposure to linoleic acid, gamma-linolenic acid, and arachidonic acid prevented alloxan-induced cytotoxicity and apoptosis in insulin-secreting cells, with gamma-linolenic acid and arachidonic acid also restoring antioxidant status and normalizing fatty acid concentrations in plasma phospholipids.
population_specificity: Insulin-secreting rat insulinoma cell line (RIN) and experimental animals (rats).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of omega-6 fatty acids (specifically arachidonic acid, AA) on tumorigenesis, particularly their role in promoting skin cancer risk and their interaction with omega-3 fatty acids.
results_summary: The study found that AA did not directly affect TPA- or EGF-induced AP-1 transactivation or cell transformation but abrogated the inhibitory effects of DHA (an omega-3 fatty acid) on these processes in a dose-dependent manner. This suggests that omega-6 fatty acids may counteract the protective effects of omega-3 fatty acids against tumorigenesis.
population_specificity: Mouse epidermal JB6 cells
interactions: AA counteracted the inhibitory effects of DHA on TPA- and EGF-induced AP-1 transactivation and cell transformation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether polyunsaturated omega-6 fatty acids (e.g., arachidonic acid) share the cytotoxic activity of docosahexaenoic acid (22:6) in tumor cells.
results_summary: The study found that cytotoxicity is unique to 22:6-containing phosphatidylcholine (PC) and not shared by PCs with other polyunsaturated omega-3 or omega-6 fatty acids, including arachidonic acid (20:4). Omega-6 fatty acids were taken up by cells but did not exhibit cytotoxic effects.
population_specificity: Cultured T27A murine leukemia cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the blood pressure-lowering effects of omega-6 fatty acids (from corn oil) versus omega-3 fatty acids (from fish oil) in elderly hypertensive subjects.
results_summary: The study found no significant between-group differences in blood pressure changes between omega-6 and omega-3 supplements, though both lowered blood pressure within groups. Omega-6 (corn oil) showed a modest reduction in standing DBP compared to baseline, but the effect was less pronounced than with fish oil.
population_specificity: Elderly hypertensive subjects (aged ≥60 years) with SBP ≥160 or DBP ≥90 mm Hg.
effective_dosage: 9 g corn oil per day (omega-6 fatty acids).
study_duration: Two 8-week treatment periods separated by a 3-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of omega-6 fatty acids (from corn oil) and omega-3 fatty acids (from menhaden oil) during the initiation and postinitiation stages of colon carcinogenesis in rats.
results_summary: High corn oil (HCO) diet during the postinitiation phase increased colon tumor incidence and multiplicity, while high menhaden oil (HFO) diet reduced these effects. The HCO diet during the initiation phase had no significant impact on carcinogenesis.
population_specificity: Male F344 rats
effective_dosage: 5% corn oil (LCO), 23.5% corn oil (HCO), or 18.5% menhaden oil plus 5% corn oil (HFO)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of omega-6 fatty acids (linoleic acid) on prostate cancer cell proliferation in various cell lines.
results_summary: Linoleic acid (omega-6) promoted cell growth in all tested cell lines except EPYP1. The study also found that low concentrations of omega-3 fatty acids (EPA) promoted growth in human prostate cancer cell lines, while higher concentrations inhibited growth.
population_specificity: Human metastatic (PC-3, LNCaP, TSU) and rat metastatic (Mat-Ly-Lu) prostate cancer cell lines, as well as rat non-metastatic epithelial cell lines (EPYP1, EPYP2, EPYP3).
effective_dosage: 1-100 ng/ml for linoleic acid; 1 ng/ml for EPA (low concentration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how varying the ratio of dietary omega-3 to omega-6 fatty acids affects the development of pancreatic preneoplastic lesions in rats.
results_summary: Increasing the omega-3 to omega-6 ratio significantly reduced preneoplastic lesion development and lowered serum prostaglandin levels. Dietary intervention with omega-3-rich fats decreased lesion formation, while omega-6-rich fats increased it.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats given azaserine at 14 days of age.
effective_dosage: Diet totaling 20% by weight of fat (specific omega-3 to omega-6 ratios not detailed).
study_duration: 4 months post-dosing (with dietary intervention at 2 months in the second experiment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids as adjuvant enteral nutrition on the GH/IGF-I axis in patients with Crohn's disease.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids in their effects on the GH/IGF-I axis. Both groups showed increases in tIGF-I, fIGF-I, and IGFBP-3, likely due to corticosteroid treatment rather than the fatty acids.
population_specificity: 31 patients with active Crohn's disease (CDAI: 186-603).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of varying dietary levels of omega-6 fatty acids (from corn oil) and omega-3 fatty acids (from Menhaden oil) on colon carcinogenesis in rats.
results_summary: High-fat diets with higher omega-3 and lower omega-6 fatty acids significantly reduced the incidence and multiplicity of colon adenocarcinomas compared to high omega-6 diets. Omega-6 fatty acids were associated with increased tumor incidence and higher colonic mucosal ornithine decarboxylase activity.
population_specificity: Male F344 rats
effective_dosage: Various combinations of corn oil (5%, 11.8%, 17.6%, 23.5%) and Menhaden oil (1%, 5.9%, 11.8%, 17.6%)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs), including Omega-6 Fatty Acids, on lipid profiles (LDL, HDL, and LDL/HDL ratio) in patients undergoing renal replacement therapy (RRT).
results_summary: The study conducted a network meta-analysis of 28 RCTs but reported ambiguous results due to mixed reports of various nutrients used in interventions. The effects of PUFAs on lipid profiles in RRT patients were not conclusively determined.
population_specificity: Patients receiving renal replacement therapy (RRT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acid supplementation on erythrocyte fatty acid levels and cytokine profiles in children recently diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD).
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 and omega-6 supplementation increased erythrocyte fatty acid levels (EPA and DHA) and reduced IL-2 cytokine levels compared to placebo. The treatment was tolerable with adherence greater than 70%.
population_specificity: Children aged 2 to under 6 years recently diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD).
effective_dosage: Daily oral supplement based on participant weight (specific amounts not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term effects of omega-6 fatty acids on inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) and inflammatory markers.
results_summary: The study found sparse outcomes for omega-6 fatty acids, suggesting little or no effect on IBD prevention, treatment, or inflammatory markers where data were available.
population_specificity: Adults with or without IBD (41,751 participants, including 13 RCTs with IBD participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different combinations of omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids on dry eye syndrome (DES) in long-term contact lens wearers, with or without topical cyclosporine.
results_summary: A properly balanced combination of omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids significantly alleviated contact lens-related DES. Topical cyclosporine further reduced cytokine production and improved DES symptoms.
population_specificity: 360 long-term contact lens wearers with dry eye syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 and -6 fatty acid supplementation could improve language development in children at risk for autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: The study found that gesture use, but not word production, increased more in children receiving omega-3 and -6 supplementation compared to the placebo group, suggesting possible effectiveness for language development in at-risk children.
population_specificity: Children at risk for ASD (n=31).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of omega-6 fatty acids, specifically gamma linolenic acid, in the prevention or treatment of atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The study found that gamma linolenic acid (an omega-6 fatty acid) was unsuccessful in preventing or treating atopic dermatitis, while omega-3 fatty acids showed potential promise in preventing allergic disorders, particularly atopic dermatitis. Further randomized controlled studies are needed to confirm these effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human nutrition context).

study_goal: To assess the effects of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs), including omega-6 fatty acids, on learning outcomes in children with specific learning disorders.
results_summary: The study found no suitable trials for inclusion, concluding there is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of PUFAs for children with specific learning disorders.
population_specificity: Children aged below 18 years with specific learning disabilities diagnosed using DSM-IV, ICD-10, or equivalent criteria, including those with co-existing developmental disorders like ADHD or autism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of omega-6 fatty acids as an adjunctive treatment for dry eye disease, focusing on their anti-inflammatory effects and symptom relief.
results_summary: Omega-6 fatty acids showed efficacy in alleviating dry eye symptoms, likely due to their anti-inflammatory properties, though further research is needed to standardize treatment protocols.
population_specificity: Patients with dry eye disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Omega-6 fatty acids (specifically linoleic acid) could improve disease progression or relapse outcomes in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients.
results_summary: Omega-6 fatty acids (11-23 g/day linoleic acid) showed no significant benefit in disease progression for MS patients. Some studies suggested slight potential benefits in relapse outcomes, but these findings were limited by poor endpoint validity.
population_specificity: 144 MS patients (general) and 65 chronic progressive MS patients.
effective_dosage: 11-23 g/day linoleic acid (general MS), 2.9-3.4 g/day linoleic acid (chronic progressive MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether postoperative administration of ω-3 and ω-6 fatty acids improves cellular hypoperfusion and lactate clearance in patients undergoing major gastric surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in serum lactate levels, complication rates, biochemical parameters, hospital stay, or mortality between patients receiving ω-3 and ω-6 fatty acids versus ω-6 fatty acids alone.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing gastric cancer surgery (n=26).
effective_dosage: Omegaven (0.2 g/kg/d) + Lipovenoes 10% (0.6 g/kg/d) for the intervention group; Lipovenoes 10% (0.8 g/kg/d) for the control group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between adipokines (leptin and adiponectin) and omega-6 fatty acids (n-6FA) in patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD).
results_summary: The study found an inverse association between plasma adiponectin and erythrocyte n-6FA in hemodialysis patients, suggesting n-6FA may promote inflammation. Leptin levels were positively associated with BMI and cholesterol but not directly linked to n-6FA effects.
population_specificity: 44 hemodialysis patients, 29 peritoneal dialysis patients, and 10 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a 10-day vegan diet versus an isocaloric, isonitrogenous omnivorous diet on daily mixed muscle protein synthesis (MPS) rates in older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in MPS rates between the vegan and omnivorous diets. The omnivorous diet resulted in higher plasma cholesterol levels (LDL, HDL, and total cholesterol) compared to the vegan diet, but no differences were observed in other cardiometabolic markers.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (72 ± 4 years, 18 males, 16 females).
effective_dosage: Not specified beyond dietary composition (60% animal protein in omnivorous diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an exclusively plant-based protein diet versus a mixed diet on muscle mass and strength gains in young men undergoing resistance training.
results_summary: Both plant-based and mixed diets resulted in similar significant increases in leg lean mass, muscle cross-sectional area, and strength, with no statistically significant differences between the groups. The study concluded that protein source does not affect resistance training-induced adaptations when protein intake is adequate.
population_specificity: Healthy young men (19 vegans and 19 omnivores, aged 26 ± 5 years).
effective_dosage: 1.6 g kg-1 day-1 of protein, adjusted via supplemental protein (soy for vegans, whey for omnivores).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the health status of omnivorous endurance runners (OR) with vegetarian (VER) and vegan endurance runners (VGR).
results_summary: The study found significant differences in health-related indicators and behaviors among OR, VER, and VGR, but specific outcomes for omnivorous diets were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 245 female and male recreational endurance runners (109 OR, 45 VER, 91 VGR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the accuracy of ChatGPT as an educational resource for parents of children undergoing Oral Immunotherapy (OIT).
results_summary: ChatGPT provided intelligible and comprehensive responses to common OIT-related questions, with healthcare practitioners rating its answers positively (average median rankings of 8.6, 8.4, and 7.8 for basic, advanced, and medical categories, respectively). However, readability was low, and understandability was reduced due to response complexity.
population_specificity: Parents of children undergoing OIT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the health effects of a traditional Daniel Fast (restricted vegan), a modified Daniel Fast (restricted omnivorous), and an unrestricted vegan diet on anthropometric and biochemical measures.
results_summary: The modified DF (omnivorous) showed a 10% decrease in total and LDL cholesterol, a 5 mmHg reduction in systolic BP, and a 2 mmHg reduction in diastolic BP, but no significant changes in insulin or oxidative stress markers compared to the traditional DF.
population_specificity: 35 subjects (6 men, 29 women) aged 18-67 years.
effective_dosage: Ad libitum meat and skim milk consumption (modified DF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 fatty acid supplementation could reduce inflammation and blood cell adhesion in patients with sickle cell disease (SCD).
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 supplementation increased DHA and EPA levels, reduced white blood cell count and monocyte integrin, and lowered NF-κB gene expression, suggesting anti-inflammatory effects. However, no significant changes were observed in other inflammatory markers like C-reactive protein or cytokines.
population_specificity: Homozygous SCD patients (HbSS) aged 5-16 years, compared with healthy controls (HbAA).
effective_dosage: Two or three capsules daily containing 277.8 mg DHA and 39.0 mg EPA, adjusted by age group (5-10 or 11-16 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of peanut oral immunotherapy (OIT) in peanut-allergic adults using real-world peanut products.
results_summary: 67% of participants achieved the primary endpoint of tolerating a cumulative dose of 1.4 g peanut protein, with a 100-fold increase in median tolerated dose. OIT also improved quality of life and showed immunological changes, though three participants withdrew due to adverse reactions.
population_specificity: Peanut-allergic adults (mean age 24.2 years, 8 female).
effective_dosage: Maintenance dose of 1000 mg (four large peanuts) daily, with updosing every two weeks.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but updosing occurred every two weeks until maintenance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how different definitions of dose "tolerance" impact reported desensitization rates in food allergen immunotherapy (AIT).
results_summary: The study found that using less objective symptoms to define dose tolerance can overestimate food-AIT efficacy by 15%, suggesting that more patient-centric outcomes may improve outcome harmonization in clinical trials.
population_specificity: Patients from three randomized-controlled trials and one real-world registry.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of combining rapid food desensitization with omalizumab as an introductory step to oral immunotherapy for managing food-induced anaphylaxis.
results_summary: The study found that the combined strategy enhanced safety and effectiveness by reducing severe allergic reactions and improving allergen tolerance, with rapid desensitization offering time and cost savings.
population_specificity: Patients with food-induced anaphylaxis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of omalizumab as an adjunct to Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) for IgE-mediated food allergy in children.
results_summary: OIT combined with omalizumab resulted in higher desensitization rates, faster allergen tolerance, and reduced adverse reactions compared to OIT alone, though long-term tolerance post-omalizumab remains uncertain.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with IgE-mediated food allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) and discuss its role in treating IgE-mediated food allergy, particularly in infants and toddlers.
results_summary: The study found that OIT is well tolerated in infants and toddlers and can lead to sustained unresponsiveness (remission) to food allergens. It recommends OIT as a treatment option for food allergy under medical supervision.
population_specificity: Infants and toddlers with IgE-mediated food allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of peanut oral immunotherapy (P-OIT) using home-measured peanut butter versus peanut avoidance in children with high-threshold peanut allergy.
results_summary: P-OIT significantly increased desensitization rates (100% success vs. 21% in avoidance) and sustained unresponsiveness (68.4% vs. 8.6%). No serious adverse events or reactions beyond grade 1 severity were reported.
population_specificity: Children aged 4 to 14 years with allergic reactions to 443 mg to 5043 mg of peanut protein.
effective_dosage: Home-measured peanut butter (exact dosage not specified, but challenges involved up to 9043 mg of peanut protein).
study_duration: 16 weeks of ad lib ingestion followed by 8 weeks of abstinence for sustained unresponsiveness testing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of different immunotherapy administration routes (subcutaneous, sublingual, oral) for treating allergies to various allergens.
results_summary: Oral immunotherapy was effective for food allergies with gastrointestinal symptoms and was noted as the only approved treatment for elderly patients due to its low risk of side effects. It was also found to be safe and effective in time-accelerated and dosage-enhanced protocols.
population_specificity: Patients with allergic conditions to pollen (trees, grasses, weeds), house dust mites, Alternaria alternata spores, and food allergies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether age or peanut-specific IgE levels independently predict remission in children undergoing Oral Immunotherapy (OIT).
results_summary: Higher baseline peanut-specific IgE levels were consistently associated with lower remission likelihood, while age showed no independent association after adjustment. The study found no evidence supporting younger age as a predictor of remission following OIT.
population_specificity: Children aged 1-10 years who completed 18 months of OIT in the PPOIT-003 RCT (n=162).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether baked milk oral immunotherapy (BMOIT) could reduce adverse reactions while inducing desensitization in milk-allergic children and to identify immunological correlates of successful BMOIT.
results_summary: BMOIT was well tolerated, with 70% of participants tolerating 4044 mg of baked milk protein by month 24 and 36.7% tolerating 2000 mg or more of unheated milk protein. Immunological changes included increased IgG4 and Tregs and decreased IgE and Th2A cells, correlating with desensitization.
population_specificity: Milk-allergic children aged 3-18 years.
effective_dosage: 4044 mg of baked milk protein (primary endpoint), 2000 mg or more of unheated milk protein (secondary endpoint).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cost-effectiveness of egg oral immunotherapy (OIT) compared to egg avoidance in school-age children and identify the most cost-effective age to start treatment.
results_summary: OIT was cost-effective when initiated at age 8 or older, with the best cost-effectiveness observed at age 12. Cost-effectiveness improved further if OIT-induced remission rates increased to ~40%. Without OIT, most children achieved natural resolution by age 24.
population_specificity: 1,000 children aged 4 years with egg allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dupilumab enhances the efficacy of oral immunotherapy (OIT) with AR101 in pediatric patients with peanut allergy.
results_summary: Dupilumab + OIT led to a 20.2% increase in patients passing a peanut protein challenge after up-dosing compared to OIT alone, though continuous dupilumab treatment during maintenance showed a non-significant 16.6% improvement. Safety was consistent with dupilumab's known profile, but it did not protect against OIT-related anaphylaxis.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (6-17 years old) with confirmed peanut allergy.
effective_dosage: 2044 mg (cumulative) of peanut protein during food challenges.
study_duration: 28-40 weeks up-dosing, followed by 24-week maintenance and 12-week post-treatment follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and feasibility of cashew nut oral immunotherapy (OIT) compared to peanut OIT, focusing on the up-dosing process and adverse reactions.
results_summary: Cashew nut OIT showed lower severity of adverse reactions and better tolerability than peanut OIT, with 91% of cashew nut-allergic patients achieving desensitization compared to 73% of peanut-allergic patients. Severe reactions were rare but more common in peanut-allergic children with high baseline IgE levels.
population_specificity: Children with cashew nut or peanut allergies treated at the University Children's Hospital Basel between 2018 and 2022.
effective_dosage: Incremental increases of 20-30% every 2 weeks until reaching a maintenance dose of 1 g of nut protein.
study_duration: 18-24 months of maintenance dose before a second oral food challenge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify metabolomic pathways associated with tolerance in food allergy and responses to oral immunotherapy (OIT), comparing sustained unresponsiveness (SU) versus transient desensitization (TD).
results_summary: The study found distinct metabolomic profiles involving bile acids, histidines, and eicosanoids in food allergy patients, with changes over OIT duration. Participants achieving SU had higher levels of immunomodulatory metabolites like lithocholate and urocanic acid, suggesting potential mechanisms of tolerance.
population_specificity: Multiethnic cohorts including healthy infants (N=384), children with asthma (N=1040), and participants in a peanut OIT trial (N=20).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of oral immunotherapy as an intervention to modify allergies and reduce severe reaction risks, while acknowledging its limitations and failure rates.
results_summary: The study found that oral immunotherapy can modify allergies but has a notable failure rate and potential for severe, life-threatening outcomes. Discontinuing therapy may increase the risk of fatal reactions, and omalizumab was suggested as an alternative for failed cases.
population_specificity: Not specified (general allergy patients implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) improves the quality of life in adults with food allergies compared to non-OIT controls.
results_summary: OIT significantly improved quality of life in adults with food allergies, with 75% achieving full desensitization. The study group showed statistically and clinically better scores in allergen avoidance, emotional impact, and overall quality of life compared to controls.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥18 years with food allergies (milk, egg, peanut, sesame, tree nuts).
effective_dosage: Median starting dose of 23.8 mg protein.
study_duration: Median of 10.3 months to reach full desensitization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a pediatric decision-aid tool to support shared decision-making regarding oral immunotherapy (OIT) initiation versus allergen avoidance for food-allergic children.
results_summary: The decision-aid demonstrated good acceptability, high decisional self-efficacy (85.9/100), and low decisional conflict (20.9/100) among caregivers, with balanced information and no bias toward a "best choice." Lower decisional conflict was linked to caregiver-reported anaphylaxis.
population_specificity: Caregivers of food-allergic children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of low-dose sesame protein oral immunotherapy (OIT) in pediatric patients with IgE-mediated sesame allergy, comparing it to standard treatment (elimination diet).
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a randomized controlled trial to assess OIT's ability to increase tolerance to sesame protein (4000 mg dose) and monitor adverse events, immunological changes, and maximum tolerated doses, but final results are not yet reported.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients aged 3-17 with confirmed IgE-mediated sesame allergy.
effective_dosage: 300 mg sesame protein (maintenance dose), administered once daily.
study_duration: Up to 18 months (including dose escalation and 3-month maintenance phase).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize racial and ethnic disparities in attitudes toward, familiarity with, and utilization of oral immunotherapy (OIT) among caregivers of children with food allergies.
results_summary: The study found that non-Hispanic Black (NHB) and Hispanic or Latino (H/L) caregivers were significantly less familiar with OIT and less likely to have initiated it compared to non-Hispanic White (NHW) caregivers, even after adjusting for household income.
population_specificity: Caregivers of children with food allergies enrolled in the Food Allergy Outcomes Related to White and African American Racial Differences cohort.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify fecal microbial predictors of Peanut Oral Immunotherapy (POIT) efficacy and understand mechanistic insights into treatment response.
results_summary: The study identified five microbial-derived bile acids enriched in fecal samples before POIT initiation that predicted treatment efficacy (AUC 0.71). POIT failure was associated with a distinct fecal microbiome with enhanced bile acid deconjugation, amino acid metabolism, and increased peanut peptide degradation.
population_specificity: Children (n=79) undergoing POIT in a double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term outcomes, risks, and benefits of oral immunotherapy (OIT) by comparing clinical outcomes (remission, desensitization without remission, and remaining allergic) in children.
results_summary: The study found that remission participants had fewer reactions, less severe reactions, and greater health-related quality of life improvement compared to desensitization without remission or allergic participants. Peanut ingestion post-treatment was higher in OIT groups than placebo, and reactions reduced over time across all groups.
population_specificity: Children who completed the PPOIT-003 randomized trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to trace historical milestones in OIT and EPIT development, describe their immunologic mechanisms, and identify areas for future research.
results_summary: OIT and EPIT originate from AIT, differing in administration routes and shorter sustained unresponsiveness periods. Progress has been made, but many questions remain before full understanding is achieved.
population_specificity: Patients with food allergies (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the reasons for discontinuation of Oral Immunotherapy (OIT), particularly focusing on social factors and adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found that social factors were the most common reason for OIT discontinuation (64%), followed by adverse effects (48%) and anxiety (34%). Gastrointestinal symptoms were the most prevalent adverse effect, while anaphylaxis contributed to discontinuation in 30% of cases.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients aged 10 months to 18 years and 2 months, treated in community pediatric allergy practices.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the biological mechanisms of food allergy and oral immunotherapy (OIT) prognosis, identify predictive biomarkers, and improve OIT accessibility.
results_summary: The study established a biobank of biological samples and clinical data but did not report specific OIT outcomes or efficacy metrics. It highlighted an interdisciplinary effort to enhance food allergy care.
population_specificity: 183 children with IgE-mediated food allergy and 27 non-allergic siblings from the Saguenay-Lac-Saint-Jean region, Canada.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify practical considerations for implementing Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) in clinical practice, focusing on office setup, staffing, and logistics.
results_summary: The study highlights the importance of proper office setup, staffing, scheduling, and on-call responsibilities for safely and effectively integrating OIT into clinical practice, beyond just products and protocols.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence on milk oral immunotherapy (OIT), discuss key studies, and provide practical information about its use in managing cow's milk allergy (CMA).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that milk OIT may protect patients from accidental exposures and allow increased milk intake, but it does not provide specific efficacy or safety data. The natural history of CMA is favorable for most, but some cases persist.
population_specificity: Children with cow's milk allergy (CMA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline key considerations for shared decision-making regarding Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) by discussing its risks, benefits, and uncertainties.
results_summary: OIT can desensitize individuals with food allergies and potentially reduce reaction severity, but it carries risks like allergic reactions, eosinophilic esophagitis, and logistical challenges, with uncertain long-term outcomes. The study emphasizes the importance of shared decision-making to align treatment with patient values and preferences.
population_specificity: Individuals with immunoglobulin E-mediated food allergies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the challenges and current state of oral immunotherapy (OIT) for fish and shellfish allergies, including practical and immunologic barriers.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that seafood OIT faces multiple challenges, such as taste, odor, cross-reactivity issues, and protein concentration changes during cooking, but suggests that motivated patients may benefit under experienced supervision.
population_specificity: Patients with fish and shellfish allergies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of tree nut oral immunotherapy (TN-OIT) as a treatment option for patients with tree nut allergy.
results_summary: The study found that TN-OIT is reasonably safe and effective, with clinical cross-reactivity noted between certain tree nuts. Nonpharmaceutical food products were identified to facilitate dosing.
population_specificity: Patients with tree nut allergy, particularly those with persistent allergy and confirmed sensitization via skin-prick or serum IgE testing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe common adverse events in Oral Immunotherapy (OIT), review their frequency and risk factors, and discuss treatment strategies to ensure patient safety and tolerability.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that OIT can cause a range of adverse events, from mild oral reactions to severe systemic reactions requiring epinephrine, and emphasizes the need for allergists to understand these reactions for safe administration.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on real-world reports from private practice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and limitations of oral immunotherapy (OIT) for food allergies, including its potential to induce desensitization and sustained unresponsiveness.
results_summary: OIT demonstrated efficacy in promoting desensitization in most treated individuals, but sustained unresponsiveness after cessation was observed only in a subset. Adverse events ranged from mild symptoms to severe reactions like anaphylaxis, with multi-allergen OIT showing favorable safety and efficacy outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with food allergies, including those with single-food and multifood allergies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the variability in Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) protocols, including initiation approaches, buildup speed, target maintenance doses, and the use of adjuvants, to understand their implications for safety and efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that OIT protocols vary widely, with most starting with an initial escalation day to identify highly allergic patients, followed by a buildup period over months to years. Protocols increasingly favor low-maintenance doses, and accelerated schedules with omalizumab may be considered for severe cases.
population_specificity: Patients with food allergies (specific population not further detailed).
effective_dosage: Doses increased every 1-2 weeks by a factor of 1.25 to 2, adapted based on symptoms (exact amounts not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature and provide practical guidance on the use of FDA-approved peanut oral immunotherapy (OIT) and shelf-bought products for treating peanut allergy.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that peanut OIT represents a significant advancement in food allergy treatment, enabling patients to access active treatment options. It emphasizes the impact on allergy practice but does not detail specific outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with peanut allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the emerging clinical practice guidelines for Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) in treating IgE-mediated food allergies, identifying areas of consensus and uncertainty.
results_summary: The study found consensus on the need for accurate diagnosis, contraindications, and proper clinical settings for OIT, but highlighted discrepancies and knowledge gaps, particularly in treating adolescents and adults. It emphasized shared decision-making due to uncertainties.
population_specificity: Patients with IgE-mediated food allergies (specific age groups not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the role of registered nurses (RNs) in the delivery of Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) within allergy/immunology interprofessional teams.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the multifaceted roles of RNs in OIT, including patient-centered care, clinical judgment, education, case management, and research collaboration, but does not report specific outcomes of OIT itself.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus is on RN roles in OIT delivery)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the optimal dose, dosing frequency, and duration of Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) maintenance to achieve sustained unresponsiveness while considering the burden of care.
results_summary: The study suggests that higher maintenance doses, more frequent dosing, and longer duration increase the likelihood of sustained unresponsiveness but also raise the burden of care. The regimen should be individualized based on patient and family treatment goals.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of single-food oral immunotherapy (OIT) versus multifood OIT for patients with multiple food allergies.
results_summary: The study found that multifood OIT is a viable option with similar outcomes to single-food OIT, offering substantial time and cost savings. Clinics proficient in single-food OIT can transition easily to multifood OIT, and patients benefit from a more convenient treatment course.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple food allergies presenting for oral immunotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and practical application of egg oral immunotherapy for patients with persistent egg allergy, focusing on dosing protocols and addressing challenges.
results_summary: The study suggests that egg oral immunotherapy can enable patients to consume small amounts of egg without allergic reactions, providing protection from accidental exposures. However, it highlights the persistence of severe phenotypes in some individuals with high egg white specific IgE levels.
population_specificity: Patients with persistent egg allergy, particularly those with high egg white specific IgE levels and sensitization to Gal d 1.
effective_dosage: Gradually increasing doses of egg (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) for food allergy, with a focus on adjunct therapies like omalizumab.
results_summary: OIT is the most evaluated therapeutic approach for food allergy but carries a risk of allergic reactions. Omalizumab shows promise in enhancing desensitization and reducing adverse reactions, while other biologics like dupilumab are under investigation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general food allergy population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the multidisciplinary involvement (e.g., dietitians and psychologists) required for optimal outcomes in oral immunotherapy for food allergy, focusing on patient education, nutritional health, and psychological support.
results_summary: The study emphasizes the critical roles of dietitians in patient education, dose preparation, and nutritional health assessment, and psychologists in addressing psychological distress and improving quality of life. It advocates for their involvement in clinical trial design and patient selection to enhance treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with food allergies and their caregivers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the adverse events and quality of life impact of sesame oral immunotherapy (OIT) in a U.S. pediatric population with sesame allergy.
results_summary: The study found that 91.3% of patients reached maintenance therapy, with common adverse reactions including gastrointestinal (91.3%), cutaneous (78.3%), and respiratory (26%) events. Quality of life improved significantly in food-related anxiety and social/dietary limitations.
population_specificity: Children (8.5 ± 4.7 years, 30% girls, 70% boys) with a documented history of sesame allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of home-based wheat oral immunotherapy (OIT) using wheat noodles in children with wheat allergies.
results_summary: The study found that 82.0% of patients achieved desensitization to 2,400 mg of wheat protein, compared to 4.5% in the control group, though 30.0% experienced anaphylaxis during the up-dosing phase. Asthma and higher sIgE to ω-5-gliadin/total IgE ratios were significant predictors of treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Korean children aged 3 to 17 years diagnosed with wheat allergies.
effective_dosage: 2,400 mg of wheat protein (via wheat noodles).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess long-term adherence rates to the milk OIT protocol and evaluate the associated risk of allergic reactions.
results_summary: Only 56% of patients adhered to the maintenance protocol (200 mL of milk at least 3 times per week). Adherent patients had significantly reduced risks of allergic reactions, anaphylaxis, healthcare visits, and medication use.
population_specificity: 50 patients who completed milk OIT and reached a maintenance dose.
effective_dosage: 200 mL of milk at least 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the safety and efficacy of Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) using heat-treated Lyophilized Peanut Protein-MH (LPP-MH) in peanut-allergic children.
results_summary: After 40 weeks of OIT, 32/33 children could consume over 300 mg of natural peanut protein, with no severe allergic reactions. By 6-12 months, most children achieved age-appropriate dietary inclusion of peanuts.
population_specificity: Peanut-allergic children with a single highest tolerated dose of <100 mg peanut protein.
study_duration: 40 weeks of treatment, with follow-up at 6-12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify metabolomic pathways associated with tolerance in food allergy and responses to oral immunotherapy (OIT), particularly comparing sustained unresponsiveness (SU) versus transient desensitization (TD).
results_summary: The study found distinct metabolomic profiles in food allergy patients, with altered histidines and bile acids. Participants achieving SU had higher levels of immunomodulatory metabolites like lithocholate and urocanic acid, suggesting potential mechanisms of tolerance in OIT.
population_specificity: Multi-ethnic cohorts including healthy infants (N=384), children with asthma (N=1040), and participants in a peanut OIT trial (N=20).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of oral immunotherapy (OIT) using enteric-coated capsules for allergic rhinitis (AR) induced by house dust mites, comparing it to subcutaneous immunotherapy (SCIT).
results_summary: After 1 year, both OIT and SCIT showed significant therapeutic effects, with OIT being more effective in reducing AR symptom scores and improving nasal provocation test results. No adverse reactions were reported in the OIT group, while SCIT had local and systemic reactions.
population_specificity: 49 patients with allergic rhinitis induced by house dust mites (24 in OIT group, 25 in SCIT group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess disparities in the use of Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) for peanut allergy based on race, ethnicity, and socioeconomic status.
results_summary: The study found significant racial and economic disparities in OIT access, with Black patients and those with lower socioeconomic status underrepresented in the treatment group. No differences in gender or ethnicity were observed between the OIT and control groups.
population_specificity: Peanut-allergic patients younger than 18 years receiving care at the University of Michigan food allergy clinics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential effects of oral Immunotherapy on the eradication rate of H. pylori in human studies.
results_summary: Three out of four studies using Immunoglobulin Y suggested significant effects on H. pylori eradication, while two out of three studies using bovine antibody found it ineffective.
population_specificity: Human populations with H. pylori infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent advances in understanding the transcriptional pathways associated with clinical outcomes of Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) for food allergy, focusing on mechanisms like desensitization and remission.
results_summary: The study identified T helper 2A cells as correlating with disease activity and modified by OIT, while molecular features at study entry may predict positive outcomes. Potential mechanisms like T cell anergy and Type 1 interferon pathways were highlighted, though gaps remain in understanding long-term immune signatures.
population_specificity: Individuals with food allergy undergoing Oral Immunotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate patient-related barriers to Oral Immunotherapy (OIT), including anxiety, taste aversion, and the role of healthcare professionals like dietitians.
results_summary: Fear of reaction was the most common barrier to OIT initiation, while taste aversion was the primary obstacle to continuation, particularly in older children. Dietitians were underutilized despite their support improving dose certainty.
population_specificity: Families currently enrolled in food OIT programs in Canada and the United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the OITcontrol app in monitoring milk and egg oral immunotherapy (OIT) compared to traditional written diaries.
results_summary: The OITcontrol app was found to be a valuable tool for monitoring OIT, improving adherence to treatment indications and dose adjustments after adverse reactions, though home reactions were recorded more frequently by the control group using written diaries.
population_specificity: Children with milk or egg allergies undergoing OIT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of slightly processed allergen/meat from fish and crustacea in oral immunotherapy (OIT) for seafood allergy, both in mouse models and clinical patients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that crustacean allergen significantly reduced anaphylactic scores in mouse models, while slightly processed meat increased oral tolerance incidence in clinical patients. Subgroup analyses highlighted the effectiveness of specific processing methods like the Maillard reaction and simple cooking.
population_specificity: Mouse models and clinical patients with seafood allergy.

study_goal: To determine the safety and effectiveness of peanut oral immunotherapy (OIT) with a slow up-dosing strategy and low maintenance dose in children aged 1 to 3 years with peanut allergy.
results_summary: After 1 year, 72% of children in the OIT group tolerated a cumulative dose of 750 mg peanut protein compared to 4% in the avoidance group. Adverse events were mild in 79% of cases, with only three doses of epinephrine administered to two individuals.
population_specificity: Children aged 1 to 3 years with peanut allergy.
effective_dosage: Initial low and increasing doses of peanut protein, with a median tolerated cumulative dose of 2,750 mg in the OIT group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review key oral immunotherapy (OIT) protocols and post-desensitization strategies for major food allergens, evaluating management choices and shared decision-making for food-allergic patients.
results_summary: The study found that OIT is emerging as a viable treatment option, with randomized controlled trials supporting its use for peanut, egg, milk, and wheat, and clinical reports for tree nuts and sesame. Protocols vary in dosing and maintenance strategies, with regular allergen exposure needed to maintain desensitization.
population_specificity: Food-allergic patients, including those allergic to peanut, egg, milk, wheat, tree nuts, and sesame.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically analyze the efficacy and safety of oral immunotherapy (OIT) combined with biological agents for treating food allergy.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that OIT has shown effectiveness in desensitization but frequently causes adverse events, including anaphylaxis, and some patients fail to achieve sustained desensitization. Biological agents like omalizumab may serve as adjunctive therapy to improve OIT outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with severe food allergy (specific population not further detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety of multifood sublingual immunotherapy (SLIT) in pediatric patients and assess its effectiveness in bypassing the buildup phase of oral immunotherapy (OIT).
results_summary: The study found SLIT to be very safe, with no life-threatening reactions and only 2.10% of patients requiring epinephrine. A subset of patients successfully bypassed OIT buildup after 1-2 years of SLIT, with 70% passing a low-dose oral food challenge.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients aged 4 to 18 years with food allergies.
effective_dosage: 2 mg protein SLIT maintenance dose, built up over 3-5 visits.
study_duration: 1 to 2 years of daily SLIT maintenance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a low-dose oral food challenge could safely bypass the build-up phase of oral immunotherapy for shrimp-allergic children.
results_summary: Of 17 children who completed the low-dose oral food challenge, 53% tolerated 300 mg shrimp protein with no reaction, while 47% had mild reactions. 94% continued daily maintenance immunotherapy without anaphylaxis.
population_specificity: Children aged 3-17 years with shrimp allergy confirmed by skin prick test, specific IgE levels, or objective IgE-mediated reactions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and efficacy of peanut allergen powder-dnfp (PTAH) oral immunotherapy in desensitizing peanut-allergic children aged 1 to <4 years.
results_summary: PTAH-treated participants showed a 73.5% desensitization rate (tolerating ≥600 mg peanut protein) compared to 6.3% in the placebo group. Most adverse events were mild to moderate, with no severe or serious treatment-related systemic allergic reactions reported.
population_specificity: Peanut-allergic children aged 1 to <4 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and factors influencing the success of Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) for IgE-mediated food allergies, including age, dose, frequency, and duration.
results_summary: OIT was found to be effective and safe in infants, increasing tolerance thresholds for common food allergens. Early initiation improved desensitization rates, even for foods with a natural tendency for allergy resolution. Ongoing studies are exploring protocol modifications and clinical monitoring tools to enhance OIT success.
population_specificity: Infants with IgE-mediated food allergies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between peanut-specific IgE and IgG4 levels and clinical outcomes in participants receiving peanut oral immunotherapy (PTAH) versus placebo.
results_summary: The study found no correlation between baseline IgE/IgG4 levels and clinical response to PTAH, but noted significant immunological changes (e.g., postscreening IgE/IgG4 ratio shifts) in the PTAH group compared to placebo. PTAH contained immunodominant allergens, inducing measurable immune changes.
population_specificity: 269 participants (202 PTAH, 67 placebo) from the PALISADE trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and risks of food oral immunotherapy (food-OIT) as an active treatment for food allergy, focusing on its impact on reactivity thresholds, reaction severity, dietary choices, anxiety, and quality of life.
results_summary: The study found that food-OIT increases the threshold of reactivity to allergenic foods, reduces reaction severity upon accidental exposure, expands dietary options, lowers anxiety, and improves quality of life, though it carries risks of allergic reactions during therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with food allergies and their families in westernised countries.

study_goal: To evaluate the clinical outcome and immune marker changes of a lightened version of egg oral immunotherapy (OIT) in children with egg allergy.
results_summary: All 18 patients in the OIT group were successfully desensitized within an average of 4.5 months, with significant immune marker changes (reduced IgE, increased IgA1, IgA2, and IgG4). Only 2 of 17 control group children tolerated egg after 1 year.
population_specificity: Egg-allergic children (18 in OIT group, 17 in control group).
effective_dosage: Egg powder with short up-dosing, maintained by egg in daily diet (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors associated with difficulties in wheat oral immunotherapy (OIT) for children with IgE-mediated wheat allergy.
results_summary: Higher initial wheat and omega-5-gliadin-specific IgE levels were significant risk factors for complications during OIT, including frequent adverse reactions or protocol deviations. Anaphylaxis during oral food challenge tests also increased complication risks.
population_specificity: Children under 18 years with a history of IgE-mediated wheat allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess shifts in IgE and IgG4 binding to peanut allergens and their epitopes in US peanut-allergic participants undergoing oral immunotherapy (OIT) with peanut allergen powder-dnfp (PTAH).
results_summary: The study found statistically significant decreases in IgE binding to intact Ara h 2, 3, and 6, with shifts towards IgG4 binding post-OIT. Increased IgG4 binding was more critical for desensitization at 12 months than decreased IgE.
population_specificity: US peanut-allergic participants (n=20) enrolled in phase 3 PTAH OIT clinical trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify baseline clinical and demographic factors that modify the effects of probiotic peanut oral immunotherapy (PPOIT) and peanut oral immunotherapy (OIT) on remission and health-related quality of life (HRQL).
results_summary: Both PPOIT and OIT were effective in inducing clinical remission and improving HRQL, but higher peanut sensitivity and concurrent allergic conditions reduced remission likelihood. Anaphylaxis history reduced remission likelihood more with PPOIT than OIT, while sex, anaphylaxis history, and age modified HRQL outcomes.
population_specificity: 201 children aged 1-10 years with challenge-confirmed peanut allergy.
effective_dosage: Cumulative 4,950-mg peanut protein at 8 weeks after treatment (specific dosing frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of early oral immunotherapy (e-OIT) in achieving sustained unresponsiveness (SU) in young children with food allergies and explore the underlying immune mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that e-OIT in children under 4 years showed a more favorable outcome in achieving SU compared to older patients, suggesting an early-life window of opportunity for intervention. However, the underlying mechanism for this higher effectiveness remains unclear.
population_specificity: Children younger than 4 years of age with food allergies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patients who completed Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) with and without Omalizumab (OMZ), identify predictors for OMZ need, and evaluate long-term OMZ use and withdrawal safety.
