results_summary: 93% of patients achieved desensitization; OMZ reduced allergic reaction rates (p < 0.001) and most patients (81%) discontinued OMZ successfully without severe reactions. Lower reaction doses during oral challenge predicted OMZ need (p = 0.037).
population_specificity: Patients with IgE-mediated food allergy, some requiring OMZ due to severe/frequent allergic reactions (10-20%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cost-effectiveness of probiotic-adjuvanted peanut oral immunotherapy (PPOIT) versus placebo in children with peanut allergy, focusing on sustained unresponsiveness and quality-adjusted life years.
results_summary: PPOIT showed significantly higher effectiveness than placebo, with a 54% sustained unresponsiveness rate versus 6%, and improved QALYs (9.05 vs. 8.63). Despite higher healthcare costs, PPOIT was deemed cost-effective at approximately $A20,000 per QALY gained.
population_specificity: 56 children aged 1-10 years with peanut allergy.
effective_dosage: Daily dose of probiotic Lactobacillus rhamnosus CGMCC 1.3724 (NCC4007) and peanut oral immunotherapy.
study_duration: 1.5 years of treatment, with 10 years total follow-up (including post-treatment and extrapolation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and safety of peanut oral immunotherapy (OIT) compared to standard care (avoidance) in inducing desensitization in children aged 1-4 years with peanut allergy.
results_summary: The study is designed to assess the proportion of children achieving a peanut eliciting dose >600 mg peanut protein after 12 months of OIT, with secondary outcomes including safety, quality of life, and immunological changes. Results are pending as the trial is ongoing.
population_specificity: Children aged 1-4 years with peanut allergy.
effective_dosage: Daily peanut OIT (specific dose not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the limitations of current oral immunotherapy (OIT) for peanut allergies and explore alternative routes to improve safety and efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that while OIT reduces allergic reactions, its strict regimen and risk of severe adverse events limit its appeal. Alternative immunotherapy routes (sublingual, epicutaneous, intranasal) may offer safer and more effective desensitization with lower allergen doses.
population_specificity: Preclinical animal models and clinical studies addressing food allergies (primarily peanut allergies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of low-dose sesame oral immunotherapy (200 mg protein) in preschoolers with sesame allergy.
results_summary: The study found that low-dose S-OIT was safe, with 32.1% of subjects experiencing no reactions during buildup and 85.7% successfully completing the exit oral food challenge. Most adverse reactions were mild (grade 1 or 2), and only one subject required epinephrine.
population_specificity: Preschoolers (median age 33.5 months) with sesame allergy, confirmed by history of objective reactions and positive skin prick tests or IgE levels.
effective_dosage: 200 mg sesame protein daily as maintenance dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immune signatures and baseline conditions related to oral immunotherapy for peanut allergy, focusing on its potential to induce sustained unresponsiveness.
results_summary: The study highlights that oral immunotherapy can reshape the immune system toward higher threshold dose reactivity, with young patients, especially those under 3 years old, showing the best chance for success. However, surrogate markers for therapy duration and response remain unclear, and further research is needed to fill knowledge gaps.
population_specificity: Peanut-allergic patients, particularly young children under 3 years old.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term safety and changes in peanut sensitization markers in individuals undergoing peanut oral immunotherapy (PTAH) over approximately 5 years.
results_summary: The study found a trend of decreasing adverse events over time, with most being mild or moderate, and improved immunologic markers (reduced peanut-specific IgE, increased IgG4, and lowered IgE:IgG4 ratio). A reduction in peanut skin prick test wheal diameter was also observed.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 4 to 17 years with peanut allergy.
effective_dosage: Initial dose escalation (6 mg over 2 days), updosing (increased every 2 weeks to 300 mg for ≥6 months), and maintenance (300 mg daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of PPI treatment in children with EoE induced by OIT versus EoE from other causes and describe the clinical and histological features of EoE+OIT.
results_summary: PPI treatment was similarly effective in both EoE+OIT and EoE-OIT groups, with high clinical and endoscopic response rates and better histological response in the EoE+OIT group.
population_specificity: 42 children (74% male, mean age 11.2) with EoE, including 11 with EoE induced by OIT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to modify and validate the OIT-PB questionnaire to assess parental burden related to oral immunotherapy for food allergies.
results_summary: The modified OIT-PB questionnaire demonstrated high reliability and validity, identifying four subscales of parental burden. Significant correlations were found between OIT-PB and other validated scales (FAQLQ-PB and SRS-18), and a negative correlation was observed between treatment effect anxiety and food intake rate.
population_specificity: Parents of children with food allergies undergoing oral immunotherapy for the first time.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between the duration of Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) treatment and the achievement of sustained unresponsiveness (SU) in children with peanut allergies.
results_summary: The study found that 71% of patients achieved SU, with the rate increasing over the therapeutic period, peaking at 2.7 person-years. The median period until SU achievement was 2.1 person-years.
population_specificity: Children with persistent peanut allergies, median starting age of 8 years, 85% with a history of anaphylaxis.
effective_dosage: Peanut dose gradually increased to 3,000 mg (795 mg peanut protein) during oral food challenge, maintained for ≥5 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the ethical and clinical implications of continuing oral immunotherapy (OIT) in patients diagnosed with eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE), despite its traditional contraindication.
results_summary: The study found that while OIT may induce EoE, most patients experience symptom resolution and histologic remission after discontinuing OIT. However, recent studies report OIT continuation even after EoE onset, creating ethical and clinical challenges.
population_specificity: Patients with eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) undergoing oral immunotherapy (OIT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish the long-term safety and efficacy of a novel red meat oral immunotherapy (OIT) for adults with galactose-alpha-1,3-galactose (alpha-gal) allergy.
results_summary: All patients who underwent OIT became tolerant to red meat, with a gradual decrease in alpha-gal sIgE concentrations over 5 years. Rare tick bites induced hypersensitivity reactions in two patients, but one patient with low sIgE levels consumed red meat uneventfully despite frequent tick bites.
population_specificity: Adults with confirmed red meat allergy due to alpha-gal sensitivity.
effective_dosage: Desensitized patients were recommended to eat at least 100 g of red meat daily for 6 months, then every other day for the next 6 months, followed by 2-3 times per week after a year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether abatacept, as an adjuvant to peanut OIT, could promote immune tolerance in peanut-allergic individuals aged 14-55 years.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but the primary outcome focuses on suppressing the OIT-induced surge in peanut-specific IgE/total IgE at 24 weeks, with sustained unresponsiveness assessed later. Preclinical data suggest potential efficacy, but human results are pending.
population_specificity: Peanut-allergic participants aged 14-55 years.
effective_dosage: Target maintenance dose of 300 mg peanut protein.
study_duration: 24 weeks for primary outcome, with follow-up assessments starting at 36 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and practical considerations of Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) for children with hen's egg (HE) or cow's milk (CM) allergies.
results_summary: OIT was found to reduce parental burden related to allergen avoidance and induce desensitization and immune tolerance, though it requires careful monitoring by specialists. Contraindications include uncontrolled asthma, malignancy, and certain autoimmune disorders, but a history of anaphylaxis or multiple food allergies does not preclude OIT.
population_specificity: Children with long-lasting allergies to hen's eggs or cow's milk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the current practices and barriers related to Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) among allergists in the United States, comparing academic and nonacademic settings.
results_summary: The survey revealed that 50% of responders offered OIT in their practice, with similar practices across academic and nonacademic settings regarding the number of foods offered, oral food challenges, and patient demographics. Key barriers included staff and time limitations, safety concerns, and inadequate compensation, with clinic space limitations being more prominent in academic settings.
population_specificity: Allergists practicing in the United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing data on clinical and immunological outcomes of peanut oral immunotherapy (pOIT) to inform best practices for selecting patients most likely to benefit from it.
results_summary: The study summarizes immunological and clinical outcomes of pOIT across different ages, suggests an ideal age range for initiating pOIT, and highlights the need for further research on optimal timing and patient selection.
population_specificity: Patients with peanut allergy, with consideration of different age groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a systematic method to estimate the protein content of common allergens in retail foods and create patient education materials for safe dietary introduction after oral immunotherapy.
results_summary: The study identified retail food equivalents for seven allergens at six serving sizes and developed 48 patient education materials, providing guidance on estimating allergen protein content systematically.
population_specificity: Patients with food allergy, particularly those undergoing oral immunotherapy or needing dietary introduction of allergens.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and factors influencing the success of Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) in increasing tolerance thresholds for IgE-mediated food allergies.
results_summary: OIT was found to be effective and safe in infants, with early initiation improving desensitization rates even for foods where natural allergy loss is common. Ongoing studies are exploring protocol modifications and clinical tools to enhance OIT success and monitoring.
population_specificity: Infants with IgE-mediated food allergies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the limitations of Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) for food allergies and explore potential strategies to enhance its safety and efficacy.
results_summary: OIT is effective at inducing desensitization to food allergens but has limitations such as a long build-up duration, high rate of adverse events, and variable effectiveness across patients. Emerging strategies, including biologics and novel therapies, show promise in improving OIT outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general food allergy population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the ethical considerations and implementation of Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) in children, focusing on principles like autonomy, beneficence, nonmaleficence, and justice.
results_summary: The study found that ethical principles are crucial in guiding OIT decisions, with shared decision-making being central to individualized care. While OIT can promote health and well-being, challenges like equity and access must be addressed.
population_specificity: Children with food allergies, particularly young children whose families act as surrogate decision-makers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if E-B-FAHF-2 improved remission rates in subjects undergoing omalizumab-facilitated multiallergen OIT.
results_summary: Omalizumab-facilitated multi-OIT was safe and effective, with 24.2% achieving remission, but E-B-FAHF-2 did not improve outcomes compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Subjects undergoing multiallergen OIT (n=33).
effective_dosage: Maintenance dose of 1000 mg of each allergen.
study_duration: 24 months of multi-OIT, plus 2 months pre-OIT and 2-month build-up phase.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the latest evidence on oral immunotherapy (OIT) for food allergy, focusing on its efficacy, safety, immune mechanisms, and ongoing research to improve therapeutic outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that OIT shows promise in raising reaction thresholds and accelerating tolerance for allergens like peanuts, eggs, and milk, but safety concerns and long-term effects remain unresolved. Growing evidence supports its efficacy, though gaps in current knowledge highlight the need for further research.
population_specificity: Individuals with food allergies, particularly to peanuts, eggs, and milk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of oral immunotherapy with peanut allergen powder-dnfp (PTAH) in reducing allergic symptoms and improving tolerance to peanut exposure in children and adolescents with peanut allergy.
results_summary: PTAH significantly reduced symptom severity and increased the proportion of participants who remained asymptomatic during peanut exposure, with notable improvements in respiratory, gastrointestinal, cardiovascular/neurological, and dermatological symptoms. The treatment also showed continued benefit with longer maintenance periods.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 4 to 17 years with peanut allergy.
effective_dosage: Maximum peanut protein doses of 1000 mg (PALISADE, ARTEMIS) and 2000 mg (ARC004) during DBPCFCs.
study_duration: Maintenance treatment durations ranged from ~6 months to ~20 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and real-world impact of Oral Immunotherapy (OIT) for IgE-mediated food allergies, focusing on desensitization, patient experience, and protocol optimization.
results_summary: Studies confirmed OIT's efficacy in desensitizing children allergic to cow's milk, eggs, and peanuts, though patient selection criteria remain non-consensual. The abstract highlights ongoing challenges, including defining long-term efficacy and optimizing protocols, while noting recent regulatory progress in peanut OIT.
population_specificity: Children with IgE-mediated food allergies (specifically cow's milk, eggs, and peanuts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a combined SLIT-peach and OIT protocol using commercial peach juice in patients with LTP syndrome.
results_summary: The combination therapy was well tolerated (80.5% for SLIT, 85% for OIT) with no severe adverse reactions, and 86.6% of patients successfully passed the final provocation. One month later, 93.3% had no dietary restrictions, and quality of life significantly improved.
population_specificity: Patients with LTP syndrome who are not sensitized to storage proteins, mostly with LTP anaphylaxis.
effective_dosage: SLIT-peach ALK followed by OIT with Granini® peach juice, progressively increased to 200 ml over 42 days.
study_duration: Approximately 82 days (40 days SLIT maintenance + 42 days OIT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether protein type or hydrolysation affects absorption from iso-osmolar oral rehydration solutions (ORS) in patients with an ileostomy.
results_summary: The study found no change in ileostomy output across the three protein-based ORS interventions, but whey protein isolate ORS showed discrete improvements in absorption proxies, including reduced fecal energy loss and improved plasma markers. The ORS were safe and well-tolerated.
population_specificity: Patients with an ileostomy (14 enrolled, 13 completed at least one intervention, 10 completed all three).
effective_dosage: 500 mL/day of ORS containing 40-48 g protein/L and 34-45 mmol sodium/L.
study_duration: Three 4-week intervention periods with >2-week washout between each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal composition of oral rehydration solutions (ORS) for diarrheic calves by evaluating water, mineral, and blood acid-base balance.
results_summary: The study found that hypotonic ORS with low sodium (HYPO) significantly improved blood acid-base balance compared to placebo, while hypertonic ORS (HYPER) resulted in greater fecal sodium losses without significant benefits. HYPO was more effective in sustaining hydration and electrolyte balance in diarrheic calves.
population_specificity: 45 diarrheic calves (age: 18 ± 3.2 days).
effective_dosage: 2.0 L of ORS (HYPER or HYPO) or placebo (CON) administered twice daily between milk meals.
study_duration: 5 days (intervention administered from day 1 to day 3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore why glucose-based oral rehydration solutions (ORS) are widely recommended but poorly adopted, and to propose a novel hypothesis regarding their effects on diarrhea.
results_summary: The study found that glucose in ORS can stimulate both intestinal absorption and secretion, potentially exacerbating diarrhea in cases where pathogens affect glucose transport. It suggests that modern ORS formulations should focus on reducing stool volume and diarrhea duration while replacing water and electrolytes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of physiological mechanisms)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of ORS tonicity (hypotonic, isotonic, hypertonic) on water, mineral, and acid-base balance in dehydrated calves.
results_summary: Low tonicity ORS were more effective at restoring water, mineral, and acid-base balance than hypertonic ORS. Hypertonic ORS led to lower blood pH and greater fecal Na+ losses compared to hypotonic and isotonic ORS.
population_specificity: Seventy-two calves with varying dehydration severity and blood base excess.
effective_dosage: 2.0 L of ORS administered twice daily (1300 and 2100 hr).
study_duration: 3 days of intervention, with monitoring for 5 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess compliance of pre-mixed and powdered ORS products with WHO osmolality guidelines and examine their osmotic shelf-life stability.
results_summary: Only one pre-mixed ORS product complied with WHO guidelines before and after storage, while five of six powdered ORS products complied with minimal variation. Osmotic stability was questionable for some products due to ingredient composition.
population_specificity: Not specified (commercially available ORS products).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the taste and compliance of two different oral rehydration solutions (ORS) among patients with short bowel syndrome (SBS) requiring home parenteral nutrition (HPN).
results_summary: Taste ratings were similar for both ORS types (7.3 vs. 7.6 on a 1-10 scale), but a significant number of participants dropped out due to poor taste or intolerance. Compliance was moderately high, with participants consuming ORS 6.0-6.6 days per week on average.
population_specificity: Patients with short bowel syndrome (SBS) requiring home parenteral nutrition (HPN) with anticipated duration >3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess knowledge and perceptions about ORS use for diarrheal disease management among health providers and caregivers in Santa Rosa, Guatemala, and recommend strategies to increase ORS adoption.
results_summary: The study found cultural beliefs influenced diarrhea treatment, with caregivers favoring bottled ORS and antidiarrheals over ORS packets. Knowledge gaps existed regarding dehydration management and ORS use.
population_specificity: Formal and informal healthcare providers and community caregivers in Santa Rosa, Guatemala.
study_duration: Data collected from July to September 2008 (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the utility of oral rehydration solution therapy (ORST) as an alternative to intravenous fluid therapy for burn injury treatment, particularly in resource-limited settings.
results_summary: The study found that ORST is beneficial in the acute phase of burn injuries, especially when intravenous rehydration is unavailable, due to its availability, ease of administration, low risk of complications, and cost-effectiveness. Further research is suggested to optimize ORST for broader burn injury applications.
population_specificity: Burn patients in resource-limited settings (e.g., battlefield, underdeveloped nations, mass casualties).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand caregiver and healthcare provider perceptions of ORS, reasons for its low use, and opportunities to expand its adoption in India and Kenya.
results_summary: Caregivers generally had positive perceptions of ORS but often prioritized antibiotics for diarrhea treatment. Misconceptions about ORS's purpose (e.g., expecting it to stop diarrhea) were common, and inappropriate treatments, including antibiotic overuse, were prevalent.
population_specificity: Caregivers and healthcare providers in India and Kenya, focusing on children under five with diarrheal disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the palatability of different flavored oral rehydration solutions (ORS) among children and determine their flavor preferences and associations with their taste preferences.
results_summary: Cola-flavored ORS was most preferred (87.9% rated it good or really good), followed by strawberry (62.1%). Children who liked cola drinks strongly preferred cola-flavored ORS, while no such association was found for strawberry. Neutral solutions were preferred by children who disliked both cola and strawberry.
population_specificity: 116 pediatric patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the palatability of three oral rehydration solutions (Pedialyte, Pediatric Electrolyte, and Enfalyte) in children.
results_summary: Pedialyte and Pediatric Electrolyte were significantly more palatable than Enfalyte, with higher taste scores and greater willingness to consume again. Volume consumed did not differ significantly between solutions.
population_specificity: 66 children aged 5 to 10 years with non-gastrointestinal concerns.
effective_dosage: Ad libitum consumption during a 15-minute period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness and modifications of Oral Rehydration Solutions (ORS), including the standard WHO-ORS and newer variations, in managing acute diarrhea and related conditions.
results_summary: The study found that WHO-ORS significantly reduces mortality in children with acute diarrhea by improving hydration, though it does not reduce stool volume or diarrhea duration. Various modifications, such as hypo-osmolar solutions and rice-based ORS, showed mixed success, with some still under investigation.
population_specificity: Children and adults with acute diarrhea, travelers' diarrhea, and patients with short bowel syndrome requiring parenteral nutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of oral rehydration solutions (ORS) on milk clotting, abomasal pH, electrolyte concentrations, and acid-base status in suckling calves, as well as their potential to treat metabolic acidosis in diarrheic calves.
results_summary: ORS did not interfere with milk clotting in the abomasum and could be administered with milk. MR-ORS mixtures with high [SID(3)] values increased serum [SID(3)] and may effectively treat metabolic acidosis in calves with diarrhea.
population_specificity: Suckling calves with abomasal cannulas

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the importance, efficacy, and underutilization of Oral Rehydration Solutions (ORS) in preventing and treating acute dehydration caused by gastroenteritis in infants.
results_summary: ORS has been proven effective for over 50 years in preventing and treating acute dehydration, significantly reducing child mortality due to diarrhea. Despite its efficacy, ORS remains underprescribed and underused, contributing to preventable dehydration and deaths.
population_specificity: Infants, particularly those with acute diarrhea or gastroenteritis.
effective_dosage: Ad libitum (as needed) during diarrhea episodes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety of rapid intravenous rehydration in severely malnourished children and compare the efficacy of three oral rehydration solutions (glucose-ORS, glucose-ORS with amylase-resistant starch, and rice-ORS).
results_summary: Intravenous rehydration was safe and effective, with no cases of overhydration or heart failure. Rice-ORS significantly reduced stool output and ORS intake compared to glucose-ORS, though all solutions were equally effective in correcting dehydration.
population_specificity: Severely malnourished children (weight/length <70% of median) aged 6-36 months with cholera.
effective_dosage: 100 mL/kg of intravenous solution for severely dehydrated children before randomization; ORS formulations had identical electrolytes.
study_duration: Acute and convalescence phases; mean duration of diarrhea was 66 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if soluble zinc chelates in oral rehydration solutions could modulate the effects of nitric oxide (NO) excess on small intestinal absorption and secretion.
results_summary: Zinc-citrate and zinc-histidine effectively removed chemically generated NO in vitro. In vivo, zinc-citrate partially reversed NO-induced potassium malabsorption but did not affect sodium or water absorption.
population_specificity: Healthy rats under anesthesia.
effective_dosage: 1 mM zinc-citrate in oral rehydration solution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the development, efficacy, and formulation of Oral Rehydration Solutions (ORS) in preventing and treating dehydration caused by acute gastroenteritis.
results_summary: The study found that ORS solutions are highly effective in managing acute gastroenteritis, with enhanced efficacy due to reduced osmolarity in newer formulations. The widespread use of ORS has significantly improved outcomes in both children and adults.
population_specificity: Children and adults with acute gastroenteritis or short gut syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and feasibility of adding zinc to oral rehydration solutions (ORS) for controlling diarrhea in adult patients with intestinal failure caused by short bowel syndrome.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results but suggests that recommendations for ORS composition in adults are based on studies of oral zinc supplementation for acute diarrhea in children. The effectiveness of zinc-enriched ORS for adults with short bowel syndrome remains unstudied.
population_specificity: Adult patients with intestinal failure caused by short bowel syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of adding oral rehydration therapy (ORT) solutions containing bicarbonate, citrate, and acetate to cow's milk on milk clotting, abomasal pH, and abomasal emptying rate in suckling calves.
results_summary: The study found that adding a BACG-ORT solution to cow's milk increased in vitro clotting time by 6 minutes but did not affect in vivo clotting. The ORT solutions increased abomasal pH by 0.3 units and slowed abomasal emptying. In vitro recommendations against bicarbonate- or citrate-containing ORT solutions with cow's milk were not supported under in vivo conditions.
population_specificity: Six male Holstein-Friesian calves, 5 to 13 days old, with abomasal cannulae.
effective_dosage: 2 L of cow's milk with ORT solutions (low bicarbonate: 25 mmol/L, acetate: 12 mmol/L, citrate: 12 mmol/L, glycine: 7 mmol/L; or formate: 58 mmol/L, acetate: 15 mmol/L).
study_duration: Single administration in a crossover design (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding zinc to an oral rehydration solution (ORS) could regulate nitric oxide metabolite synthesis in zinc-deficient rat intestines, potentially improving intestinal function and zinc status.
results_summary: The study found that ORS with zinc (ORS+Zn) increased plasma zinc levels, normalized nitric oxide synthase activity, reduced NF-kappaB DNA binding activity, and improved intestinal villi absorption compared to ORS without zinc. These results suggest zinc-enhanced ORS may aid recovery from diarrhea and reduce recurrence risks.
population_specificity: Young male rats fed a zinc-deficient diet to mimic recurrent diarrheal conditions in humans.
study_duration: Two days of ORS administration following three weeks of zinc-deficient diet and five days of cathartic-induced diarrhea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of low-sodium low-glucose ORS and rice-based hypo-osmolar ORS with standard WHO glucose ORS in treating severe cholera in children.
results_summary: The rice-based hypo-osmolar ORS significantly reduced stool output, ORS consumption, and diarrhea duration compared to WHO-ORS and glucose-based hypo-osmolar ORS. All treatments were administered alongside tetracycline.
population_specificity: Children aged 2-10 years with severe cholera (Vibrio cholerae-positive).
effective_dosage: Tetracycline at 50 mg/kg/day in 4 divided doses for 3 days (ORS dosages not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of two hypotonic oral rehydration solutions with different osmolarities and the addition of Lactobacillus GG in treating acute diarrhea in young children.
results_summary: Early administration of Lactobacillus GG combined with a reduced osmolarity oral rehydration solution (224 mosmol/l) resulted in the shortest duration of diarrhea, best weight gain, and fastest correction of acidosis. Further reduction of osmolarity did not show additional benefits.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-36 months hospitalized for acute diarrhea.
effective_dosage: Not specified (osmolarities: 224 mosmol/l and 204 mosmol/l; Na+ 60 mmol/l, glucose 84 mmol/l or 64 mmol/l).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a packaged ready-to-mix rice oral rehydration solution (ORS) to the standard glucose ORS in treating childhood diarrhoea.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the rice ORS and standard glucose ORS in stool output, ORS intake, duration of diarrhoea, or weight gain during follow-up. Both treatments had similar rates of persistent diarrhoea episodes (2%).
population_specificity: Children aged 3-35 months with a history of watery diarrhoea for 72 hours or less.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the gastric emptying rates and electrolyte concentration changes of different oral rehydration solutions (ORS) in horses at rest and after exercise.
results_summary: The study found that 90% of the ORS was emptied from the stomach within 15 minutes of administration, regardless of solution type or exercise condition. Electrolyte concentrations did not differ between treatments but changed significantly over time, suggesting gastric emptying does not significantly impact rehydration.
population_specificity: Standardbred horses
effective_dosage: Single dose of 8 liters via nasogastric tube
study_duration: Measurements taken at 15-minute intervals for one hour

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether modified tapioca starch (Textra) improves sodium, potassium, water, and glucose absorption in oral rehydration solutions for malnourished and well-fed rats.
results_summary: In protein-deficient rats, Textra significantly enhanced sodium, potassium, and water absorption at 5 g/l and 10 g/l, with glucose absorption improving only at 10 g/l. In well-fed rats, Textra improved sodium and water absorption at 5 g/l but not at 10 g/l, with no effect on potassium absorption or water influx:efflux ratio.
population_specificity: Protein-deficient and well-fed rats.
effective_dosage: 0 g/l, 5 g/l, and 10 g/l of Textra in oral rehydration solution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a conventional (WHO-type) and a nutritional oral rehydration solution (ORS) on plasma urea, creatinine, and glomerular filtration rate (GFR) in calves with diarrhea.
results_summary: The study found that changes in urea and creatinine did not accurately reflect pre-renal failure. The nutritional ORS improved GFR, while the WHO-type solution worsened it further.
population_specificity: Calves with diarrhea

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if cereal-based oral rehydration solutions (CBORS) could be safely and effectively prepared and administered by low-income parents, and if CBORS were as effective as commercial glucose-based ORS in maintaining hydration and reducing illness severity.
results_summary: CBORS did not show a clinically significant advantage over glucose-based ORS. Mixing errors occurred in a small percentage of cases, but most children had normal serum sodium levels. Children refused CBORS more often than Pedialyte, and fluid intake was lower in CBORS groups, but there were no significant differences in vomiting, stooling, or duration of diarrhea.
population_specificity: Children aged 4 to 36 months discharged from emergency departments and health centers with acute diarrheal disease.
study_duration: Until illness resolved (daily follow-up by study nurse)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of an oral electrolyte solution made with rice syrup solids versus a glucose-based solution in reducing fecal output and promoting fluid and electrolyte absorption in infants with diarrhea.
results_summary: The rice syrup solids solution reduced fecal output more effectively than the glucose-based solution in the early hours of treatment and improved absorption of fluid, sodium, and potassium. In some infants, this rapid rehydration may prevent hospitalization.
population_specificity: Infants with diarrhea
study_duration: Early hours of treatment (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acceptability of prepackaged rice-based and flavored glucose-based ORS solutions with standard glucose-based ORS and determine if presenting rice-based ORS as a diarrhea-stopping solution enhanced its acceptability.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in ORS consumption among the three types (rice-based, flavored, and standard glucose-based). Presenting rice-based ORS as a diarrhea-stopping solution did not increase consumption. Reactions to all ORS types were favorable but similar across groups.
population_specificity: 437 non-dehydrated children under five years old with acute diarrhea.
effective_dosage: Not specified (consumption measured in mL/kg/24 h).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the volume and duration of oral rehydration solution administration in children with diarrhea and assess the influence of maternal knowledge and contextual factors.
results_summary: The study found that oral rehydration solutions were given in smaller volumes and for shorter durations than recommended, with low daily administration rates. Most children received other fluids, but their effectiveness in preventing dehydration was unclear.
population_specificity: Children with diarrhea and their mothers across seven sites in Africa, Asia, and Latin America.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding 90 mmol/L L-glutamine to standard WHO-ORS provided any additional therapeutic benefit for treating dehydration in infants with acute non-cholera diarrhea.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in diarrheal stool output, duration of diarrhea, or ORS volume required for hydration between the glutamine-based ORS and standard WHO-ORS groups. The glutamine-based ORS did not offer any additional therapeutic advantage over standard WHO-ORS.
population_specificity: Male infants aged >1 month and <1 year with acute non-cholera diarrhea and dehydration.
effective_dosage: 90 mmol/L L-glutamine added to standard WHO-ORS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of oral rehydration solutions (containing 60-90 mmol/l of sodium) combined with diuretics in managing mild neonatal hyperparathyroidism as an alternative to surgical intervention.
results_summary: The study found that oral rehydration solutions, when combined with diuretics, successfully maintained normal serum calcium levels in a neonate with primary hyperparathyroidism. The approach was deemed a viable initial treatment for mild cases, posing no specific risks.
population_specificity: Neonates with mild primary hyperparathyroidism.
effective_dosage: Oral rehydration solutions containing 60-90 mmol/l of sodium (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different oral rehydration solutions (ORS) on intestinal water and electrolyte transport in humans.
results_summary: Solution VI (hypotonic ORS) demonstrated the highest water absorption, significantly outperforming other solutions, including the WHO standard (solution II). Sodium absorption was highest with solution II, but solution VI still showed clinically meaningful absorption.
population_specificity: Humans (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
effective_dosage: Various compositions (mmol/l) of ORS were tested (solutions II-VI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of first-generation (glucosalan and citroglucosalan) and second-generation (rice and salt-based) oral rehydration solutions (ORS) in treating patients with acute intestinal infections.
results_summary: The study found that second-generation ORS (rice and salt-based) was more effective than first-generation solutions, providing not only detoxification and rehydration but also serving as a food source. Clinical and biochemical parameters supported these findings.
population_specificity: 150 patients with food toxicoinfections.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of two oral rehydration solutions (Gastrolyte and Glucolyte) in children with acute gastroenteritis and mild to moderate dehydration.
results_summary: Gastrolyte resulted in significantly fewer vomiting episodes and lower stool volume compared to Glucolyte, though differences in dehydration correction, diarrhea duration, and hospital stay were not significant. No adverse drug reactions occurred, and oral rehydration therapy was deemed safe and effective.
population_specificity: Children aged 1-10 years with acute gastroenteritis and mild or moderate dehydration (n = 45).
effective_dosage: Gastrolyte (60 mmol/l sodium, 1.8% glucose, 240 mosm/l) and Glucolyte (26 mmol/l sodium, 2.7% glucose, 3.6% sucrose, 340 mOsm/l).
study_duration: Up to 24 hours (with specific analysis at 8 hours and 0-24 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of two oral rehydration solutions (ORS-90 and ORS-60) in treating acute diarrhea in infants, focusing on osmolality differences.
results_summary: The study found that ORS-60 (lower osmolality) resulted in fewer cases requiring intravenous rehydration (2.5%) compared to ORS-90 (8.3%). Both solutions corrected hypernatremia and hyponatremia similarly, with no significant differences in sodium or potassium levels.
population_specificity: 186 infants suffering from acute diarrhea.
effective_dosage: ORS-90 (sodium 60 mmol/L, glucose 90 mmol/L, osmolality 311 mOsm/kg) and ORS-60 (sodium 60 mmol/L, glucose 90 mmol/L, osmolality 240 mOsm/kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and advantages of glucose polymer-based oral rehydration solutions (primarily rice-based) against traditional glucose-based solutions in treating acute diarrhea.
results_summary: The study found that glucose polymers from rice-based solutions were absorbed faster, reduced diarrhea duration and volume, and improved net absorption of glucose, sodium, and water compared to glucose-based solutions. These solutions also offered cost benefits and avoided osmotic overload.
population_specificity: Rats (small intestine absorption study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of glucose-based and cereal-based oral rehydration solutions and a mixed meal on jejunal water and ionic transport in dogs.
results_summary: Both glucose-based and cereal-based rehydration solutions significantly increased jejunal absorption of water and electrolytes, with no difference between the two solutions, though both were less effective than a mixed meal. The study suggests these effects may be mediated by a neurohumoral mechanism independent of direct luminal nutrient contact.
population_specificity: Dogs with proximal jejunal Thiry-Vella fistulae.
study_duration: Each study consisted of a 1-hour basal period followed by a 3-hour experimental period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of two oral rehydration solutions (ORS-60 and ORS-26) in children and infants with acute diarrhea and mild to moderate dehydration.
results_summary: ORS-60 significantly reduced stool volume within the first eight hours compared to ORS-26, led to earlier cessation of diarrhea (64% vs. 31% by 24 hours), and improved clinical condition in more patients (84% vs. 60%). No adverse drug reactions occurred, and no significant differences were found in dehydration levels, total diarrhea duration, or hospital stay.
population_specificity: Children and infants with acute diarrhea and mild to moderate dehydration.
effective_dosage: ORS-60 (60 mmol/L sodium, 1.8% glucose); ORS-26 (26 mmol/L sodium, 2.7% glucose, 3.6% sucrose).
study_duration: Intervention effects were assessed up to 24 hours, with follow-up points for clinical condition and dehydration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the optimal composition of oral rehydration solutions (ORS) and compare new formulations to established ones using animal models.
results_summary: The study found that hypotonic ORS (osmolality ≤240 mosm/kg) with sodium concentrations of 50-60 mmol/L and glucose concentrations of 90-111 mmol/L showed superior water absorption. Animal models also supported the use of glucose polymer and food-based ORS, though results must be interpreted cautiously due to physiologic limitations.
population_specificity: Healthy and diseased small intestine of rats (rotavirus-infected or cholera toxin-exposed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of two oral rehydration solutions (ORS 1 and ORS 2) in treating dehydration and diarrhea in calves, focusing on plasma volume expansion and acidosis correction.
results_summary: ORS 2 demonstrated superior performance in water absorption, plasma volume expansion, acidosis correction, and peripheral perfusion compared to ORS 1, though mortality rates in clinical cases did not differ significantly.
population_specificity: Calves (isolated intestinal loops, experimentally dehydrated, experimentally induced diarrhea, and clinical cases of diarrhea).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gastric emptying patterns of rice powder electrolyte solution and glucose electrolyte solution in acute cholera patients and recovered individuals.
results_summary: The study found no differences in gastric emptying between the two solutions during acute cholera or recovery, with rapid emptying observed in both cases, supporting their clinical efficacy in fast purging cholera patients.
population_specificity: Adult patients with acute cholera, some re-tested 16 days post-recovery.
study_duration: Single administration during acute phase and repeat 16 days later.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of cereal-based oral rehydration solutions (maize, millet, sorghum, rice) against the standard WHO/Unicef glucose-based solution in treating acute diarrhoea with moderate to severe dehydration.
results_summary: The study found that all cereal-based oral rehydration solutions were as effective as the standard glucose-based solution in terms of intake, stool output, duration of diarrhoea, and weight gain at 24, 48, and 72 hours post-treatment.
population_specificity: 257 boys aged 4-55 months with acute diarrhoea and moderate to severe dehydration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of three training methods for rural women in correctly reconstituting Oral Rehydration Solutions (ORS).
results_summary: Group II, which received verbal instructions plus a demonstration, achieved near-ideal ORS reconstitution, followed by Group III (using pre-marked bags) and Group I (verbal instructions only).
population_specificity: Rural women
effective_dosage: Entire contents of a sachet in half a litre of water

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of three different oral rehydration solutions (ORS) with varying sodium, glucose, and glycine compositions in treating acute gastroenteritis in young children.
results_summary: All three ORS formulations were safe and effective for rehydration and correcting biochemical abnormalities, with similar clinical outcomes across groups. However, carbohydrate intolerance was more prevalent in children who received the high-glucose ORS.
population_specificity: Children under 2 years old admitted to a London hospital with acute gastroenteritis.
effective_dosage: Three ORS formulations: (1) Na+ 35, glucose 200 mmol/L; (2) Na+ 60, glucose 111 mmol/L; (3) Na+ 50, glucose 50, glycine 50 mmol/L.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but outcomes were assessed at 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the usage rates and safety of home-made oral rehydration solutions (LGS) in preventing dehydration due to diarrhoea in a community programme in Bangladesh.
results_summary: The overall usage of LGS for all diarrhoea episodes was 5-10%, but for severe diarrhoea or cholera, it was 25-52%. Mothers' ability to prepare a safe solution declined after six months and was worse in the Second Phase of the programme.
population_specificity: Households in Bangladesh, particularly mothers trained by the BRAC programme.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the need for improved oral rehydration solutions (ORS) and assess experimental models for developing and testing new formulations.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that oral rehydration therapy is effective for mild to moderate dehydration but notes the lack of a definitive model for assessing ORS formulations. Various techniques, such as radioactive tracer methods and perfusion techniques, are used to study gastric emptying and intestinal absorption, though each has limitations.
population_specificity: Patients suffering from mild to moderate dehydration.
